user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_check_response_header_token_ci:
```c
bool
MHD_check_response_header_token_ci (const struct MHD_Response *response,
                                    const char *key,
                                    size_t key_len,
                                    const char *token,
                                    size_t token_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  if ( (NULL == key) ||
       ('\0' == key[0]) ||
       (NULL == token) ||
       ('\0' == token[0]) )
    return false;

  /* Token must not contain binary zero! */
  mhd_assert (strlen (token) == token_len);

  for (pos = response->first_header;
       NULL != pos;
       pos = pos->next)
  {
    if ( (pos->kind == MHD_HEADER_KIND) &&
         (key_len == pos->header_size) &&
         MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (pos->header,
                                        key,
                                        key_len) &&
         MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (pos->value,
                                      token,
                                      token_len) )
      return true;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ( (pos->kind == MHD_HEADER_KIND) &&
         (key_len == pos->header_size) &&
         MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_ (pos->header,
                                        key,
                                        key_len) &&
         MHD_str_has_token_caseless_ (pos->value,
                                      token,
                                      token_len) )
      return true;
explanation: Other code fragments do not need investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 because they already use const-qualified types where applicable or do not involve pointer-to-object qualifications: the function parameters are declared const (const struct MHD_Response *response, const char *key, const char *token), the NULL/empty checks on key and token only read through those const pointers, and strlen(token) and the called helper functions (MHD_str_equal_caseless_bin_n_, MHD_str_has_token_caseless_) accept/read const char * data — so no non-const pointer-to-object is being unnecessarily used there. The only places where a pointer to a non-const type is declared or propagated from a const-qualified input (response) are the local iterator 'pos' and its subsequent uses (accessing pos->header, pos->value, pos->next, pos->kind, pos->header_size). These should be investigated to determine whether they can/should be const-qualified (for example: const struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos) to comply with Rule 8.13. No other fragments in the function present pointer-to-non-const opportunities that appear to violate the rule.
